author: m.kalinin
content: I believe in this case EL won't keep an invalid block in its chain and will return SYNCING as there is no parent for the block you have submitted later. Then, according to the Engine API spec, the next `newPayload` should result in `status: IVALID, lvh: parent.parent_hash`.

author: potuz
content: I didn't understand, so the child returns SYNCING as the first part of the reply or INVALID as the last part?. But mostly this this not much about the spec as it is about implementations. And I ask cause I'm changing something in Prysm because I believe ELs cannot ever return this combination unless they just happen to finish syncing between the new Payload and FCU for the parent block

author: m.kalinin
content: The child returns SYNCING as the invalid parent was discarded, and then once that invalid parent is somehow found EL will return INVALID with grandparent_hash. I understand you're asking about implementations, it makes sense as not sure if all impls follow the spec in such scenarios

author: potuz
content: I don't understand: when will it return INVALID? I'm not calling twice. If it returns SYNCING it requests the parent (I assume you refer to this) but after finding the parent it ditches everything, it won't return INVALID cause the new Payload call has already returned
